Android is a mobile operating system based on a modified version of the Linux kernel and other open-source software. It is designed primarily for touchscreen mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets.
Key points about Android:
Android Inc. was founded in Palo Alto, California, in October 2003 by Andy Rubin, Rich Miner, Nick Sears, and Chris White.
Initially, Android aimed to develop an operating system for digital cameras but later shifted its focus to smartphones.
Google acquired Android Inc. in 2005.
The first commercial Android device, the HTC Dream, was launched in September 2008.
Android is developed by a consortium of developers known as the Open Handset Alliance.
At its core, Android is known as the Android Open Source Project (AOSP) and is free and open-source software (FOSS).
Most devices run on the proprietary Android version developed by Google, which includes additional closed-source software (Google Mobile Services).
